org.gearvrf.animation

Class GVRMaterialAnimation

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.animation.GVRAnimation
      • org.gearvrf.animation.GVRMaterialAnimation
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    GVRColorAnimation, GVROpacityAnimation

    public abstract class GVRMaterialAnimation
extends GVRAnimation
    Animate a GVRMaterial. The constructors cast their target parameter to a protected final GVRMaterial mMaterial field.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected GVRMaterial mMaterial 

      • Fields inherited from class org.gearvrf.animation.GVRAnimation

        DEFAULT_REPEAT_COUNT

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Modifier Constructor and Description
      protected GVRMaterialAnimation(GVRHybridObject target, float duration)
      Deprecated. 
      Using this overload reduces 'constructor fan-out' and thus makes your life a bit easier - but at the cost of replacing compile-time type checking with run-time type checking, which is more expensive and can miss errors in code if you don't test every path through your code.
      protected GVRMaterialAnimation(GVRMaterial target, float duration)
      Sets the protected final GVRMaterial mMaterial field without doing any runtime checks.
      protected GVRMaterialAnimation(GVRSceneObject target, float duration)
      Sets the protected final GVRMaterial mMaterial field without doing any runtime checks.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      protected static GVRMaterial getMaterial(GVRSceneObject sceneObject)
      'Knows how' to get a material from a scene object - a bit smaller than inline code, and protects you from any changes (however unlikely) in the object hierarchy.

    • Field Detail

      • mMaterial

        protected final GVRMaterial mMaterial

    • Constructor Detail

      • GVRMaterialAnimation

        protected GVRMaterialAnimation(GVRHybridObject target,
                               float duration)
        Deprecated. Using this overload reduces 'constructor fan-out' and thus makes your life a bit easier - but at the cost of replacing compile-time type checking with run-time type checking, which is more expensive and can miss errors in code if you don't test every path through your code.
        Sets the protected final GVRMaterial mMaterial field.
        Parameters:
        target - May be a GVRMaterial or a GVRSceneObject - does runtime checks.
        duration - The animation duration, in seconds.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If target is neither a GVRMaterial nor a GVRSceneObject

      • GVRMaterialAnimation

        protected GVRMaterialAnimation(GVRMaterial target,
                               float duration)
        Sets the protected final GVRMaterial mMaterial field without doing any runtime checks.
        Parameters:
        target - GVRMaterial to animate.
        duration - The animation duration, in seconds.

      • GVRMaterialAnimation

        protected GVRMaterialAnimation(GVRSceneObject target,
                               float duration)
        Sets the protected final GVRMaterial mMaterial field without doing any runtime checks.

        This constructor is included to be orthogonal ;-) but you probably won't use it, as most derived classes will have final fields of their own to set. Rather than replicate the final field setting code, the best pattern is to write a 'master' constructor, and call it via this(getMaterial(target), duration), ...); - see GVROpacityAnimation.GVROpacityAnimation(GVRSceneObject, float, float) for an example.

        Parameters:
        target - GVRSceneObject containing a GVRMaterial
        duration - The animation duration, in seconds.

    • Method Detail

      • getMaterial

        protected static GVRMaterial getMaterial(GVRSceneObject sceneObject)
        'Knows how' to get a material from a scene object - a bit smaller than inline code, and protects you from any changes (however unlikely) in the object hierarchy.
